body: uv_fatal_error() normally prints an error message.  Do you know what it said?

Because uv_fatal_error print error message to stderr, so i cannot get error message in my log file.
But i have another stack as below, and i got error message by redirect stderr to console, the error message says:
```
getsockopt:(10014) System detected use a invalid pointer in system call.
```
I had checked the code, the pointer pass to getsockopt is allocated in stack, and size of the memory which the pointer point to is calculated by ```sizeof```, i don't know what to do next. 

STACK TEXT:
```
06f1f538 73cbf012 00000000 00000538 71a51f5e MainFrame!uv_fatal_error+0x80 [g:mojo-releasemojo_v3.5.1src etatlasatlasplatformwin32libuvsrcwinerror.c @ 61]

WARNING: Frame IP not in any known module. Following frames may be wrong.

06f1f9a4 73c91ec7 3088f3aa 717ced74 06c33ee8 MainFrame!uv_loop_init+0x1d [g:mojo-releasemojo_v3.5.1src etatlasatlasplatformwin32libuvsrcwincore.c @ 133]
06f1fab4 73c62a44 3088f212 717ced74 06c33c28 MainFrame!wukong::net::EventLoop::EventLoop+0x167 [g:mojo-releasemojo_v3.5.1src etatlasatlaswukong eteventloop.cpp @ 137]
06f1fb0c 73aa0092 3088f232 00901910 06c33c28 MainFrame!wukong::lwp::UserAgent::UserAgent+0xa4 [g:mojo-releasemojo_v3.5.1src etatlasatlaswukonglwpuseragent.cpp @ 21]

I don't know either.  I doubt it's a libuv issue or we would have received (plenty) more bug reports.  Is there anything unusual about your setup or the way you build/link/load libuv?

Yes, before i commit this issue, i checked all the opened issue, but didn't find similar situation. Maybe there is some thing wrong of the way i use libuv, i will check again to find why. Thanks for your warm help.

This is odd, you initialize libuv with a call to `uv_loop_init`, which takes only a pointer to `uv_loop_t`. 

Can you check if the pointer passed to `uv_loop_init` is valid?
Also, can you check if other apps that use libuv (e.g. node) work on your setup?

Your first stack trace points to https://github.com/libuv/libuv/blob/v1.x/src/win/winsock.c#L148

Your second triggers this: https://github.com/libuv/libuv/blob/v1.x/src/win/winsock.c#L133-L138

I'm going to address the second one, since your later reported error seems to name getsockopt:

it returns *Bad address*:

The system detected an invalid pointer address in attempting to use a pointer argument of a call. This error occurs if an application passes an invalid pointer value, or if the length of the buffer is too small. For instance, if the length of an argument, which is a sockaddr structure, is smaller than the sizeof(sockaddr).

If you can reliably reproduce the bug, I would suggest for you to try a bigger buffer to that getopt and report back if it the error still occurs. 

What operating system are you using (exact version)?
what it will be if i comment the code of win_sock_init ？ can libuv work correctly？
Ok，so the only way is to finding out what the problem is。。。

I receive a crash report today, and its stack is the same as I posted at first , crashed at line 148 of file winsock.c, then i contact my customer, and install Nodejs in his computer, when i start nodejs, it also crashed. So i comment the ipv6 detect code, build a new software for my customer, and it works well. @saghul

@ljxt523 do you have any details about your user configuration? OS version, language, etc?

Also, is the logged error still `getsockopt:(10014) System detected use a invalid pointer in system call.`? And does the assert happen on [winsock.c:148](https://github.com/libuv/libuv/blob/v1.9.0/src/win/winsock.c#L148) or [winsock.c:138](https://github.com/libuv/libuv/blob/v1.9.0/src/win/winsock.c#L138)
error is :socket(10106)Service provider failed to initialize. OS version is windows 10 Professional, but i don't know the exact OS version. Assert happened on winsock.c:148. @bzoz

issue.title: Electron crashes on the user's PC

repository.name: electron
repository.description: :electron: Build cross-platform desktop apps with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS

issue.body:
One of the our application's users has a problem starting electron executable. It even happens with original executable available to download from releases page without additional modifications on our side.

We've tested the following electron versions: 2.0.10, 3.0.5 and all have the same behavior for this specific user.  
 
* Operating System (Platform and Version): Windows 7

**Actual behavior**
electron.exe starts and fails silently not reaching our code.

**Additional Information**
Here is stack trace from crash dump for version 3.0.5. It was collected using ProcDump  (options -ma -e 1 -w electron) and WinDbg (with debug symbols for version 3.0.5).
```

issue.title: remove abort when detect IPv6 support failed
issue.body:
These's two reasons to avoid abort application since invalid socket check:
1. https://github.com/libuv/libuv/issues/1425


2. google search "create  socket  10106", found many similar issues that create socket failed
